title: Rising Democratic Star Survives Close Call in Houston
abstract: Lina Hidalgo, a progressive, won re-election as Harris County judge by a slim margin against a first-time candidate who focused on crime.

multimedia.caption: Lina Hidalgo, a Democrat who led Harris County in Texas, ran for re-election against Alexandra del Moral Mealer, a political newcomer.

title: Price of Diesel, Which Powers the Economy, Is Still Climbing
abstract: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is one reason that the fuel is scarce. Another is a series of yearslong, intertwined events that cover the globe.

multimedia.caption: Over the last year, the cost of diesel has increased more than 40 percent, compared with 11 percent for gasoline.

title: How Democrats Used the Abortion Debate to Hold Off a Red Wave
abstract: In the first major election post-Roe, Democrats tied abortion rights to everyday economics and tapped into fears about the rise of right-wing Republicans.
byline: By Lisa Lerer and Elizabeth Dias

multimedia.caption: An abortion rights supporter last week in Taylor, Mich. The resolution passed.

title: In Arizona’s race for governor, Hobbs defies expectations and takes a narrow lead.
abstract: The Democratic candidate’s mild manner has been a counterweight to her rival Kari Lake’s charismatic and antagonistic style.

title: Trump Under Fire From Within G.O.P. After Midterms
abstract: “Republicans have followed Donald Trump off the side of a cliff,” a longtime adviser said.
byline: By Michael C. Bender and Maggie Haberman

title: With House Majority in Play, a New Class Takes Shape
abstract: The Republican ranks grew more extreme and slightly more diverse, while Democrats added several young liberals to their caucus.
byline: By Emily Cochrane and Catie Edmondson

title: What We Know Now About the Midterms
abstract: Some of the dust has settled, and a clearer picture is emerging of Tuesday’s surprising, sometimes nuanced results.

multimedia.caption: A weathered campaign sign hanging on a fence in Searchlight, Nev., on Tuesday. “Republicans have followed Donald Trump off the side of a cliff,” said one longtime adviser to the former president.

title: In New Book, Pence Reflects on Trump and Jan. 6
abstract: “You’re too honest,” President Donald J. Trump said as he pressured his vice president to intervene to block Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.

multimedia.caption: Vice President Mike Pence and President Donald Trump during a rally in November 2020. In a new book, Mr. Pence describes the president’s pressure campaign on him to intervene in certifying the election.
multimedia.copyright: Doug Mills/The New York Times

title: Democrats Hold Onto Contested State Legislative Chambers
abstract: Going into the election, Republicans held control in a majority of statehouses. By Wednesday, Democrats had flipped at least one Midwestern chamber.

title: Concessions are making a modest but notable comeback in 2022.
abstract: Two years after former President Donald J. Trump rejected the results of the election, many of his supporters embraced the rituals of losing amicably.

title: If Democrats Lose the House, They May Have New York to Blame
abstract: Republicans flipped four congressional seats in New York, the most of any state in the country. How did this happen in one of the nation’s most liberal states?

multimedia.caption: The Republican candidate for governor, Lee Zeldin, helped his party make inroads in pockets of Brooklyn that normally lean Democratic.

title: What Republicans Are Saying About Tuesday Night
abstract: The midterms’ results showed the limits of “Team Crazy,” in the words of Representative Peter Meijer — one of many harsh judgments coursing through a demoralized Republican Party.

multimedia.caption: Supporters of Don Bolduc at his election night party in Manchester, N.H. After the primary, he tried to walk back his claims that Democrats stole the 2020 election from Donald Trump.

title: Unwilling to Hold Their Nose and Vote, Ticket-Splitters Make Their Mark
abstract: Some midterm voters seemed more inclined to support candidates of different parties this year, emphasizing contender quality over partisan identity.
byline: By Katie Glueck and Ruth Igielnik

multimedia.caption: Voters in Cobb County, Ga., on Tuesday. In Georgia, there was a sizable gap in support for Gov. Brian Kemp and Herschel Walker, the Republicans’ Senate nominee.

title: What Many Pennsylvanians Saw in Fetterman
abstract: By reinventing his Senate campaign after a stroke, Lt. Gov. John Fetterman ended up connecting with voters who responded to his saga of loss and comeback.

multimedia.caption: Lt. Gov. John Fetterman greeted union steelworkers at a canvassing event in Coatesville, Pa., the morning before Election Day.

title: A rare win for MSNBC over CNN in the election night ratings battle.
abstract: Tuesday’s overall viewership, down sharply from 2018, was the smallest total prime-time audience for a midterm election night since 2014.

title: Ukraine Peace Talks Remain Distant Even as Moscow Signals a Retreat
abstract: President Biden and European leaders say they cannot push Ukraine and Russia into negotiations, though some U.S. lawmakers are questioning aid for an open-ended war.
byline: By Michael Crowley, Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes

multimedia.caption: Ukrainian soldiers ride atop an armored vehicle. President Biden and European leaders are hard-pressed to describe a plausible endgame to the conflict that would be acceptable to both sides.
multimedia.copyright: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

title: McCarthy Announces Speaker Bid, as Republicans Grasp for House Majority
abstract: With many races unresolved, the top House Republican rushed to declare victory and alert his colleagues that he still meant to seek the top post, even as he toiled to shore up his right flank.

multimedia.caption: Representative Kevin McCarthy spent much of Wednesday shoring up his position among grouchy Republicans after a close election night.

title: Supreme Court Closely Divided in Case on Native American Adoptions
abstract: In considering the constitutionality of the Indian Child Welfare Act, the justices explored congressional power and equal protection principles.

multimedia.caption: Demonstrators outside the Supreme Court on Wednesday. The decision in the four consolidated cases could have profound implications for the status of Native Americans in areas far beyond family law.

title: Where the Midterms Mattered Most for Abortion Access
abstract: Voters supported abortion rights in several states and elected governors friendly to access in some of the most competitive races. Other elections remain too close to call.
byline: By Allison McCann, Amy Schoenfeld Walker, John-Michael Murphy and Sarah Cahalan
des_facet: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)

title: Elected to House in 2018, Most Democratic Women Are Hanging On
abstract: Many were centrists with strong national security credentials and were elected in the anti-Trump midterm wave four years ago. But most survived this year, even in tough G.O.P.-leaning districts.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

title: Here are the uncalled races that could determine control of Congress.
abstract: Both chambers of Congress remained up for grabs, with crucial contests that could determine control yet to be called.

title: McCarthy Announces Run for Speaker as Scalise Lines Up for No. 2
abstract: Even with control of the House undecided, Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California, announced his bid in a letter to his colleagues.

title: Republican Defeats 2-Term Democrat to Win Iowa House Seat
abstract: Cindy Axne was one of seven House Democrats to carry a Trump district in 2020, but could not hold off Zach Nunn, a state senator and Air Force veteran.

multimedia.caption: Zach Nunn, a Republican state senator, defeated a two-term Democrat, Representative Cindy Axne, to win the House seat from Iowa’s Third Congressional District.

title: Van Orden, Republican Who Attended Jan. 6 Rally, Wins Wisconsin House Seat
abstract: Derrick Van Orden, a Navy SEAL who rallied at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, beat Brad Pfaff, a Democratic state senator, flipping a House seat in rural Wisconsin.

multimedia.caption: Derrick Van Orden, a retired Navy SEAL who rallied at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, ran against a Democratic state senator, Brad Pfaff, for a House seat in rural Wisconsin.
multimedia.copyright: Scott Olson/Getty Images
